bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, March 10, [1941]

div1.p: Truby acknowledges his error in saying “northwest” instead of “southwest” in regard to the location of the yellow fever grounds.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, March 10, [1941]
div1.opener:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
Monday A.M. Mar. 10-
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your air mail letter arrived
by special delivery at 730 A.M. just
as I was getting up. Am sending
the corrected letter back at once.

I cant see have I happened to
say “northwest” instead of southwest for
the maps you sent me have convinced
me of the error I have been
making all these years. It was hard
to realize that the porch of the bachelor
quarter, where we all congregated
in the evenings, did not face due
north. I have always remembered
the north star as straight ahead of
us as we looked out over the Gulf.
But of course I was wrong.
I am glad you discovered the
mistake in time to make the correction.

I have just received a nice letter
from Mr. Kellogg and was pleased
AC/1
to note that they (he & the artist) did
not “razz” me for my boldness
in trying to criticize the sketches
you sent me. No one realizes
better than I do that my views on
the artistic side of the question are
worthless. However, I did know the
personnel and the place where the
historical work was done and if
I can help them any in getting the
things I do know about, correctly
portrayed, it will be gratifying
to me. I have also received the
two prints of the paintings and
am very glad to have them.

I don't apprehend that you
will have the slighted trouble in
convincing the Cubans of the correctness
of your investigation &c. the camps &
no doubt they will be much chagrined
over this careless action in the first
place, but they will realize that the
mistake will have to be corrected without
any more publicity about their ignorance
of the historical events which took place in
their midst. Good luck!
